_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary


In June 1996, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued the Risk Management Program Standard (RMP Standard) (40 CFR, Part 68).  Regulated under the Clean Air Act Amendments (CAAA), Section 112(r), the RMP Standard requires facilities that store large amounts of listed hazardous chemical substances to prepare and implement risk management plans to reduce the probability of accidental releases and minimize the health risks to the public and the environment in the event of a release.  The RMP Standard regulates 77 listed toxic substances and 63 listed flammable substances.  The RMP Standard applies to an estimated 7,200 public and private drinking water and wastewater treatment facilities nationwide where chlorine and/or ammonia are used as disinfectants.  When properly used, chlorine has proven to be both safe and effective.

The two Gallup Pump Station/Water Chlorination Facilities (GPSWCF), Yah-ta-hey and Santa Fe, supply water to residential, commercial and industrial users.  Yah-ta-hey stores and uses one regulated chemical, anhydrous chlorine, in quantities higher than the threshold quantities.  The term anhydrous chlorine and chlorine are used interchangeably and specifically refer to a chemical listed in the RMP Standard.  

The chlorine is used to disinfect drinking water and prevent the spread of waterborne diseases.  At Yah-ta-hey, the chlorine is stored within a building in two 1-ton containers.  The total maximum intended inventory at Yah-ta-hey is 4,000 pounds. The chlorine is liquefied under pressure in the 1-ton containers.  Chlorine is drawn as a gas in an alternating manner from the two 1-ton containers through a vacuum feed system.  The gaseous chlorine is then metered into a solution through two chlorinators.  The chlorine solution is then fed to a distribution line injection point.  

Minimizing Risk
The major driving force in the development of the RMP Standard is reducing the risk to public health by minimizing the

potential of a chemical release.  The GPSWCF have a multi-layer system in place to meet this goal.  The RMProgram includes the following: (1) properly trained operators to safely handle chlorine; (2) chlorine detectors located where chlorine is stored and/or used; and (3) chemical release prevention and emergency response plans in place.  Trained personnel respond to chlorine alarms to assess whether a chlorine release poses an imminent danger to employees or the public.  While a significant release is unlikely, the emergency response plans have been developed for just such an occurrence.  The emergency response plans include procedures to be followed by operators trained to take appropriate action including contacting the City of Gallup Fire Department and New Mexico State Police. 

Management System
Within the management and administrative roles of the GPSWCF, responsibility has been defined to coordinate and implement the RMProgram.  Overall development and management of the RMProgram is the responsibility of the RMProgram Manager.  The Water Systems Superintendent is the designated RMProgram Manager.  The RMProgram Coordinator reports to the RMProgram Manager and is responsible for the day-to-day coordination and implementation of the RMProgram.  The Assistant Superintendent is the designated RMProgram Coordinator.  The RMProgram Coordinator will delegate various GPSWCF operators to assist in the implementation of the RMProgram.
